Date maintenance tags and general fixes
/* Use and definition of the term */
/* Marc Bloch and sociological views of feudalism */
/* Debating the origins of English feudalism */
/* Ganshof and the classic view of feudalism */
/* Ganshof and the classic view of feudalism */
/* Debating the origins of English feudalism */
Preliminary restructuring of the first part; introducing 'The model' vision (which in fact reflects the current article quite accurately). See discussion.
Moved the India section. This is disputable, all objections are welcome (see discussion)
Merged two sections dealing with the concept history (see discussion)
Integrated the 'Etymology' section into 'History of feudalism'; inconsitancies have surfaced as result; please, consider this to be a first step and help out!
/* Revolt against the term feudalism */ Zotero glitches ;-)
/* Revolt against the term feudalism */ Removed some old vandalism (?) and reformated the reference

The original version does not imply that bishops and abbots were laity. Note the use of the semi-colon.
Laity are non-offical members of the Church, volunteers. Clergy are the official's of the church, for example: bishops, cardinals, the pope, etc. As the article now implies, the bishop is clergy.
